trans-unit.source: Using linked templates with Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Using linked templates with Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Describes how to use linked templates in an Azure Resource Manager template to create a modular template solution. Shows how to pass parameters values, specify a parameter file, and dynamically created URLs.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to use linked templates in an Azure Resource Manager template to create a modular template solution. Shows how to pass parameters values, specify a parameter file, and dynamically created URLs.

trans-unit.source: From within one Azure Resource Manager template, you can link to another template which enables you to decompose your deployment into a set of targeted, purpose-specific templates.
trans-unit.target: From within one Azure Resource Manager template, you can link to another template which enables you to decompose your deployment into a set of targeted, purpose-specific templates.

trans-unit.source: Just as with decomposing an application into a number of code classes, decomposition provides benefits in terms of testing, re-use, and readability.
trans-unit.target: Just as with decomposing an application into a number of code classes, decomposition provides benefits in terms of testing, re-use, and readability.

trans-unit.source: You can pass parameters from a main template to a linked template, and those parameters can directly map to parameters or variables exposed by the calling template.
trans-unit.target: You can pass parameters from a main template to a linked template, and those parameters can directly map to parameters or variables exposed by the calling template.

trans-unit.source: The linked template can also pass an output variable back to the source template, enabling a two-way data exchange between templates.
trans-unit.target: The linked template can also pass an output variable back to the source template, enabling a two-way data exchange between templates.

trans-unit.source: You create a link between two templates by adding a deployment resource within the main template that points to the linked template.
trans-unit.target: You create a link between two templates by adding a deployment resource within the main template that points to the linked template.

trans-unit.source: You set the templateLink property to the URI of the linked template.
trans-unit.target: You set the templateLink property to the URI of the linked template.

trans-unit.source: You can provide parameter values for the linked template either by specifying the values directly in your template or by linking to a parameter file.
trans-unit.target: You can provide parameter values for the linked template either by specifying the values directly in your template or by linking to a parameter file.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the parameters property to specify a paramter value directly.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the parameters property to specify a paramter value directly.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager must be able to access the linked template, which means you cannot specify a local file for the linked template.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager must be able to access the linked template, which means you cannot specify a local file for the linked template.

trans-unit.source: You can only provide a URI value that includes either http or https.
trans-unit.target: You can only provide a URI value that includes either http or https.

trans-unit.source: One option is to place your linked template in a storage account, and use the URI for that item, such as shown below.
trans-unit.target: One option is to place your linked template in a storage account, and use the URI for that item, such as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The next example uses the parametersLink property to link to a parameter file.
trans-unit.target: The next example uses the parametersLink property to link to a parameter file.

trans-unit.source: The the URI value for the linked parameter file cannot be a local file, and must include either http or https.
trans-unit.target: The the URI value for the linked parameter file cannot be a local file, and must include either http or https.

trans-unit.source: The previous examples showed hard-coded URL values for the template links.
trans-unit.target: The previous examples showed hard-coded URL values for the template links.

trans-unit.source: This approach might work for a simple template but it does not work well when working with a large set of modular templates.
trans-unit.target: This approach might work for a simple template but it does not work well when working with a large set of modular templates.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you can create a static variable that stores a base URL for the main template and then dynamically create URLs for the linked templates from that base URL.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you can create a static variable that stores a base URL for the main template and then dynamically create URLs for the linked templates from that base URL.

trans-unit.source: The benefit of this approach is you can easily move or fork the template because you only need to change the static variable in the main template.
trans-unit.target: The benefit of this approach is you can easily move or fork the template because you only need to change the static variable in the main template.

trans-unit.source: The main template passes the correct URIs throughout the decomposed template.
trans-unit.target: The main template passes the correct URIs throughout the decomposed template.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to use a base URL to create two URLs for linked templates (sharedTemplateUrl and vmTemplate).
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to use a base URL to create two URLs for linked templates (sharedTemplateUrl and vmTemplate).

trans-unit.source: If you need to pass a value from linked template to the main template, you can create a value in outputs section of the linked template.
trans-unit.target: If you need to pass a value from linked template to the main template, you can create a value in outputs section of the linked template.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see <linkText>Sharing State in Azure Resource Manager Templates</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an example, see <linkText>Sharing State in Azure Resource Manager Templates</linkText><title></title>.
